'If BTC Falls, So Does the Pentagon,' Eric Trump Says Bitcoin Will Be the Last Asset Standing in Global Meltdown
Source: ccn.com    Published: 2025-11-07 13:41:05

Trump lays out his case for why Bitcoin isn't just surviving, but destined to outlast everything. | Credit: Getty Images. At the Blockchain Futurist Conference in Florida, Eric Trump spoke less like a politician and more like a man trying to make sense of a new world. Standing before a room full of crypto founders, miners, and retail investors, he traced his own journey from skeptic to believer — one that began, he said, just four or five years ago. He talked about Bitcoin's (BTC) energy consumption, about inflation and hard assets, and what he sees as a broken financial system that keeps ordinary people locked out. The tone was part curiosity, part conviction — a glimpse into how the Trump family's younger son has found his footing in the crypto space. Try Our Recommended Crypto Exchanges Sponsored Disclosure We sometimes use affiliate links in our content, when clicking on those we might receive a commission at no extra cost to you. By using this website you agree to our terms and conditions and privacy policy. Bitunix promotions Receive up to $100,000 worth of exclusive gifts for newcomers upon registration. Coins 151 Claim Offer Bitget promotions Earn rewards worth up to 5,000 USDT on your first deposit Coins 88 Claim Offer WEEX promotions Enjoy up to 30,000 USDT Bonus when you sign up and complete tasks. Coins 207 Claim Offer On a stretch of Texas desert, a massive warehouse hums with electricity, 600 yards long, packed with thousands of computers mining Bitcoin. To Eric Trump, this industrial fortress isn't just a business; it's a revelation. “I was a guy who didn't understand this world until four or five years ago,” he admitted. “I've spent a lot of time studying it.” That study, he says, changed everything. He now believes the same energy that fuels these mining rigs also protects the future of finance. “It [Trump's mining facility] uses about two and a half times the power of the city of White Plains,” he said, “and it's protecting about 2.5% of the world's Bitcoin.” Speaking on energy, Trump doubled down on Bitcoin with an argument that is as audacious as it is absolute. The younger Trump claimed that Bitcoin's energy network is so vast that if it were to collapse, the rest of the digital world would fall with it. “If Bitcoin went down — congratulations, the Pentagon's gone,” he said. “Congratulations, Amazon's gone. Congratulations, Google's gone. JPMorgan doesn't stand a chance.” In his view, the energy that protects the Bitcoin network exceeds the defensive capacity of entire nations. “The energy used to safeguard Bitcoin would be that of major, major countries around the world,” he said. And if anyone thinks quantum computing could break it, Trump is unconvinced. “You don't think that a quantum computer would have already taken out Bank of America? You don't think your Amazon account would already be gone?” he asked. “Bitcoin would actually be the last in a series of entities to fall.” For Trump, that resilience is proof not just of Bitcoin's security — but of its permanence. Ironically, Eric Trump admitted to the panel that he wasn't this ‘locked-in' into Bitcoin a few years ago, and neither were his friends. “We believe in great assets, and great assets build great wealth,” he said. “I truly believe that Bitcoin's a great asset—that's why I'm buying it.” He recalled a friend in private wealth management who once dismissed crypto as “funny money.” Eighteen months later, the same banker called back to say he was now recommending clients put “2 to 5%” of their portfolios into Bitcoin. To Trump, that's evidence the tide has turned. “We're winning this race right now,” he told the crowd. He compares crypto's current stage to the internet in 1999 — still young, still misunderstood, but prepared for exponential growth. Speaking on growth and permanence, in classic Trumpian fashion, he tied the argument to inflation and politics. “I think Biden did the greatest disservice to America of any president in history with his inflationary policies,” he said. Those policies, he argued, only reward people “with hard assets”—owners of homes, steel, or Bitcoin—while crushing “the young guy, the young girl who just came out of school and is trying to build up the American dream.” “Bitcoin is the solution to so much of it,” he declared. For Trump, crypto represents a new path to financial self-reliance. A way for people without famous last names or hundreds of millions in collateral to access credit and opportunity. “You have $100,000 in Bitcoin,” he said, “you can borrow 80% of it … You can buy your first home or start your first business.” That, he said, “is financial freedom.” “Go to JPMorgan and try and do that,” he said of borrowing against assets. “Good luck… unless you've got a last name like ours,” he quipped. That imbalance, he argued, is what cryptocurrency can fix. “Crypto is financial freedom for the masses that never existed before and has only existed to a very select few.” And he made clear who he's rooting against. “There's no person in the world that wants to see this industry beat the big banks more than I do,” he said. “Bitcoin's gonna lead the way.” Eric Trump may not have his father's bombast, but his rhetoric channels the same populist chord—pitting ordinary Americans against entrenched power. In his view, Bitcoin isn't just a digital asset; it's a rebellion against inflation, bureaucracy, and legacy finance itself. “We're really on the front end of it,” he said. “I believe in it with every ounce of my soul.” For Trump, the promise of crypto isn't about speculation—it's about access. A chance, as he put it, “to live the American dream.” Top Picks for Bitcoin Best Exchanges for Bitcoin Get A Great Offer When You Join These Exchanges Buy Bitcoin Fast & Easy How To Buy Bitcoin With a Credit Card Now Best Online Casinos for Bitcoin See Our Picks for the Best Crypto Gambling Sites

The Next PayPal? How AI And Blockchain Are Rewriting Digital Payments
Source: Forbes    Published: 2025-11-07 13:15:00

BySandy Carter, Contributor. For the last two decades that I've been paying online, PayPal has been my default. Why? It's safe, easy, and fast. But now that model is shifting. When you combine AI and blockchain, you get something entirely new: software or AI agents that act on our behalf, not just process a payment. According to Boston Consulting Group (BCG), global payments revenue is expected to reach $2.4 trillion by 2029, with agentic AI, digital currencies and real-time payments shaping the change. To show some of these shifts, I'd like to discuss three companies that I've had the chance to talk to recently. Bankr, Olas Pearl, and the fast-rising TON chat wallet ecosystem are all doing fascinating things in this space. Each one changes the game for online payments. I loved my conversation with Danielle Brown-Wolf, who leads growth at Bankr. She explained the simple goal of Bankr: to reach people where they already spend their time and solve one of the biggest pain points in crypto: accessibility. Bankr is a conversational, onchain AI agent that lives at bankr.bot and is also accessible on X and Telegram. It turns your social handle into a wallet login, powered by Privy, and executes real transactions directly from chat. You can send a message like “Buy $100 of ETH” and the agent will process the transaction, bridge across chains if needed, and record everything transparently on the blockchain. Every interaction is verifiable and happens in real time. This approach removes friction for everyday users who might not be familiar with decentralized wallets or seed phrases. Bankr lives where the audience already is.Deployer, the founder, of Bankr, told me that "AI agents will provide more financial opportunities to more people because they handle the complex part for you. Bankr is already doing this, analyzing the market and teaching people how to trade all through simple conversation." On X and Telegram, your social handle becomes your wallet login. You type a simple instruction, and the agent executes it, with every transaction recorded on the blockchain. I watched Bankr run technical analysis, place limit orders, settle a sports wager on Polymarket, and list an NFT on OpenSea, all from social feeds and a private terminal. This is more than trading. It's a payments and value transfer layer that feels like a conversation. Someone posts a pick for the game. A friend replies, “Bankr, place 50 on the Eagles.” The action happens right there in public, and others can copy it with one reply. Groups that never thought of themselves as crypto users are suddenly moving money together because the wallet feels like chat, not finance. The product focuses on safety and recovery. Accounts are non-custodial through Privy. Users can back up with email or sign in through Telegram or Farcaster if their X handle is suspended. Gas fees are covered. Links to Basecan give instant proof of what happened. Bankr even turned a security feature with Blockaid into a live demo by asking the agent to buy a known fake token. The agent refused in public and explained why. That's how you build trust. Danielle Brown Wolf, Head of Growth at Bankr, calls this “the PayPal moment for crypto.” In our conversation, she said “Bankr brings real payments into everyday conversations. When you can send or invest money as easily as you tweet, that's when digital finance finally becomes mainstream.” The analogy fits. PayPal made payments as simple as an email address. Bankr is doing the same with a social handle and an intelligent agent that can understand intent and act. It's software that lives where the customer already is. I spoke with David Minarsch, the co-founder of Valory AG, the team behind the Olas network. Their latest launch, Pearl v1, introduces a simple idea. It's an AI agent marketplace. According to Salesforce, by 2030, consumers will have personal AI agents acting on our behalf and will handle everything from planning our schedules to managing our finances. People can browse, create, and launch autonomous agents on a decentralized platform that functions like a marketplace. They start by setting a goal and configuring what they want the agent to do. Once it's created, they can fund it with a card or wallet, and it operates independently while remaining fully under your control. Every action the agent takes is recorded onchain, creating a complete and transparent history. Nothing runs behind closed servers, so your keys, data, and decisions stay private and secure. Because the agents live on a decentralized network rather than a single company's cloud, they continue to function even if part of the system goes offline. In simple terms, it's a place where anyone can build and own AI-powered agents that work for them directly, without relying on centralized platforms. Why does this matter for payments? Commerce is full of small but repetitive tasks that humans still perform by hand, like invoice matching, subscription updates, split payments, rewards, and fee management. In chatting with David Minarsch, Cofounder of Valory, he told me that they “see a future where every individual can deploy their own on-chain AI agent. And it will be one that manages money, data, and decisions transparently. The goal isn't to replace people; it's to empower them with digital teammates that they fully own.” Pearl gives developers a way to create specialized agents that execute those jobs from start to finish with verifiable results. It looks like an app store, but the apps are workers that move value according to clear rules you set. One example, a DeFi trading agent named Modius, produced a strong return in just a few months and did it with full on-chain transparency. The future is clear. As the catalog grows, many of these agents will go beyond trading. They'll handle payments, reconcile wallets, and streamline everyday financial tasks that still rely on email or manual approvals today. The third space to watch is the TON wallet ecosystem inside Telegram. It pairs a massive user base with chat-native money. Wallets live under the same keyboard people already use to message friends, brands, and creators. The next step is easy to imagine: intelligent agents that become the front door to payments inside those chats. Think about a customer support bot that issues refunds after verifying an order, or a creator's bot that sells a digital good and automatically splits revenue among collaborators. A small business agent could invoice a group chat and divide the bill across multiple wallets. None of this needs a checkout page. It all happens inside the conversation, with payments recorded on the blockchain and receipts visible to both sides. TON's biggest advantage is scale, and Goodies shows why that matters. Goodies is a Telegram mini app built on TON that blends collectibles, brands, and payments in one place. When I tried it, I watched sticker packs from Kung Fu Panda, Pudgy Penguins, and Lamborghini sell out in seconds. There's already a thriving secondary market for these stickers, where people buy and trade them directly inside Telegram. In chatting with Luca Netz, the CEO of Pengu, he talked to about the strategy. “Embedding brand Intellectural Property (IP) into daily habitual (GM) and conversational moments through memes and GIFs has been a strategy that we caught early on with Pudgy Penguins. Now with tokenization of stickers on Telegram, there's a new layer of ownership and expression unfolding.” It feels like if NFTs and emojis had a baby, fun, social, and simple. I had the chance to spend time with Danny Wheeler, Key Advisor at the Goodies Marketplace. This was just after their amazing launch with Kung Fu Panda and Pudgy Penguins. He told me in that conversation that “our goal is to build the world's first chat native economy. Every brand sticker, every collectible on TON, is proof that digital commerce can be instant, emotional, and transparent. When someone sends a sticker, they're not just sharing an emoji but they're sharing ownership and culture.” Each drop combines pop culture with blockchain in a way that feels natural and mainstream. You tap, pay, and own it. No setup. No friction. Just an experience that turns digital art into instant commerce. This is what digital payments look like when AI, culture, and blockchain work together. PayPal isn't standing still either. The company has been quietly reinventing itself for the new digital era, experimenting with stablecoins, AI-driven fraud detection, and blockchain infrastructure to stay relevant in a world moving toward decentralized finance. Its launch of PayPal USD (PYUSD) marked one of the first times a major payments provider issued its own fully backed stablecoin, signaling that even legacy platforms see the shift coming. PayPal is also expanding into new areas of cross-border payments, merchant automation, and crypto accessibility, working to stay the default for both traditional users and the next generation of digital wallets. What I saw at their Developer Days was also an impressive vision of where AI Agents are heading. Their vision shows even established leaders are thinking about autonomy, personalization, and intelligence inside payments. All three of these companies share the same pattern. They meet users where they already are. They turn plain language into secure actions. They keep ownership and transparency with the user. They hide the crypto complexity but preserve trust and control. Bankr shows how conversational wallets can turn social feeds into payment hubs. Pearl shows how agent stores can automate financial workflows. TON and Goodies show how chat and culture can merge into a new kind of payment experience. Cards and banks will still exist, but more payments will start and finish inside conversations, managed by agents people can trust and verify. That's the part that feels like the next PayPal. Not a new button on a checkout page, but a new way the internet moves money.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Exclusive: Stripe-backed startup Tempo leads $25 million raise for crypto infrastructure firm Commonware
Source: Fortune    Published: 2025-11-07 13:01:31

Ben Weiss is a crypto reporter at Fortune. A high-profile project launched by fintech giant Stripe and crypto VC firm Paradigm has just made its first venture bet. On Friday, Tempo, a payments-focused blockchain, announced it's led a $25 million fundraise for the crypto infrastructure company Commonware. As part of the arrangement, the Stripe-backed project will work with Commonware to develop methods to process blockchain payments more quickly, Paradigm general partner and CTO Georgios Konstantopoulos said in a blog post. Patrick O'Grady, founder of Commonware, declined to name other participants in the fundraise for his startup, which develops open-source code to allow others to launch their own blockchains. O'Grady also declined to disclose the valuation for his firm following the Tempo-led raise, but said it was a “significant increase” over the valuation in Commonware's seed round, which Pitchbook reports as $63 million. “Usage and distribution is way more important than money as a startup,” he told Fortune. “If we can short circuit that process and have a deep relationship, multi-year relationship, with a great team, instead of raising maybe a traditional round from a venture fund, that was the opportunity that Tempo presented.” Tempo's investment into Commonware isn't its first splashy move since Stripe and Paradigm officially unveiled the project in September. The payments-focused blockchain company has acquired the crypto startup Ithaca and hired Dankrad Feist, a high-profile researcher who contributed to the development of the Ethereum blockchain. Tempo has also increased its headcount from around five employees in August to now between 40 and 50, according to a person familiar with the company, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss private business information. It's rare for a startup to make an acquisition, a big hire, and significant investment so early on since it launched, but Tempo has the backing of some of the biggest names in tech and crypto. Stripe is a payments goliath that's worth more than $100 billion. Paradigm is one of the top venture capital firms in crypto. And Tempo's design partners include heavyweights like OpenAI, Anthropic, and Shopify. The Stripe-linked startup also has a hefty war chest. It's raised $500 million at a $5 billion valuation from some of the top VCs in Silicon Valley, including Thrive Capital, Greenoaks, Sequoia, and Ribbit Capital, Fortune first reported. “We think that they're going to do just as good of a job, or better, showing off what Commonware can do than what we can do,” said O'Grady, the founder of Commonware, in reference to Tempo. Founded in 2024, Commonware has only seven employees (including O'Grady) and four customers, but it's already profitable, he said. It makes money through helping companies deploy as well as interface with its open-source software, and each customer on average generates more than $1 million in annual revenue. “We have now a bit of a backlog of people that want to work with us,” O'Grady added. © 2025 Fortune Media IP Limited. All Rights Reserved. WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


An innovative blockchain framework for strengthening security and efficiency in banking
Source: Nature    Published: 2025-11-07 12:10:42

Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles and JavaScript. Advertisement Scientific Reports volume 15, Article number: 39029 (2025) Cite this article Blockchain technology is revolutionizing industries by fundamentally transforming data management and storage practices. Traditional banking systems, however, continue to face challenges such as dependency on intermediaries, lack of transparency, vulnerability to fraud, and restricted accessibility. To overcome this limitation, we propose an innovative blockchain framework built on the Ethereum platform to enhance security and efficiency in banking. The proposed system eliminates intermediaries by using Ethereum-based smart contracts to enable secure, automated peer-to-peer (P2P) deposits, withdrawals, and transfers while incorporating a user-friendly interface with MetaMask and custom wallets for accessibility. The architecture was implemented and tested on the Sepolia Ethereum Testnet using Solidity, Ether.js, and React.js, ensuring seamless interaction between the smart contract and the user interface. Our experimental evaluation demonstrated significant improvements in transaction speed, transparency, and operational efficiency compared to traditional systems, with near real-time processing and automated verification. Performance benchmarking showed competitive latency and throughput, while gas cost analysis highlighted trade-offs in transaction expenses compared to conventional banking. These findings suggest that our blockchain framework has strong potential to address long-standing inefficiencies in the financial sector. While challenges remain, including scalability and regulatory considerations, this work offers a concrete and impactful step toward the practical adoption of blockchain in mainstream banking. The financial landscape is undergoing a significant transformation driven by the emergence of innovative technologies. Among these, Blockchain technology stands out for its potential to revolutionize how we conduct Banking and Mobile payments1. This paper explores blockchain integration into these critical financial processes, proposing a blockchain-based approach for achieving greater efficiency and security. Traditional Banking systems, while well-established, often need to be improved. Transaction speeds can be sluggish and hampered by centralized infrastructures and intermediary institutions. Transparency can be limited, with users often needing more clear visibility into transaction details and fees. Costs associated with cross-border payments can be high, further burdened by complex regulations and exchange rates. Mobile payments, on the other hand, offer undeniable convenience. However, concerns regarding data security and fraud prevention persist. Specifically, centralized data storage creates single points of failure, making systems vulnerable to large-scale data breaches, insider threats, and denial-of-service attacks. Centralized control of user data creates potential vulnerabilities, and disputes can be cumbersome to resolve within traditional mobile payment frameworks2,3,4. Blockchain technology, with its core principles of decentralization, immutability, and cryptography, offers a compelling solution to address these challenges. It fosters a distributed ledger system, eliminating the need for centralized control and intermediaries. This translates to faster transaction processing, with data securely stored across a network of computers, making it tamper-proof and auditable by all participants. Additionally, blockchain significantly reduces the reliance on traditional third-party verification, streamlining processes and potentially reducing costs associated with cross-border transactions. This paper embarks on a comprehensive exploration of blockchain technology, delving into its core functionalities and specific applications within the banking and mobile payment domains2,1. We will dissect how blockchain can streamline transaction processing by removing intermediaries and enabling expedited settlements. We will explore how its inherent cryptographic security safeguards user data and financial information, mitigating fraud risks. Furthermore, we will examine how blockchain fosters transparency by providing a shared, immutable record of all transactions,accessible to authorized participants. The potential benefits extend far beyond technological advancements. We will analyze how a blockchain-based approach empowers financial institutions to streamline operations, reduce costs, and offer innovative financial products. For end-users, the advantages translate to faster, more secure, and potentially lower-cost transactions and greater control over their financial data.3,4 By meticulously examining the opportunities and challenges associated with blockchain integration, this paper aims to contribute significantly to the ongoing discourse on the future of secure and efficient banking and mobile payments. We will not only illuminate the transformative potential of this technology but also provide a critical analysis of the hurdles that need to be overcome for widespread adoption. These hurdles include regulatory uncertainty, scalability limitations regarding transaction throughput, interoperability challenges with existing legacy financial systems, user education requirements, and the complexities of private key management. Ultimately, this paper seeks to pave the way for a future where blockchain technology becomes the cornerstone of a secure, efficient, and inclusive financial ecosystem. Our system leverages the capabilities of Ethereum to offer a suite of financial functionalities, including: Account creation via metamask or custom wallet Users can create an account either through Metamask, a well-known cryptocurrency wallet, or a custom wallet designed for specific needs. Metamask simplifies interaction with Ethereum-based decentralized applications, while a custom wallet offers more tailored control and flexibility. Deposit ether into the smart contract After account creation, users can deposit Ether (ETH) into a designated smart contract. The deposit process is secure and recorded immutably on the blockchain. The smart contract registers the transaction and makes the deposited Ether available for future interactions like withdrawals or transfers. Withdraw ether from the smart contract Users can request to withdraw their Ether from the smart contract at any time, following the conditions set by the contract. The system verifies the withdrawal request, ensuring sufficient funds are available before securely transferring the Ether back to the user's connected wallet. Transfer ether from one user account to another The platform also supports Ether transfers between user accounts. These peer-to-peer transactions are processed through the smart contract, ensuring that the sender has sufficient funds before completing the transfer. This system ensures security and transparency, leveraging the decentralized nature of blockchain technology to execute transactions without intermediaries. This demonstrates the real-world applicability of blockchain technology within the realm of financial services. Other features could also be easily included in the system, but we will demonstrate our system with the three basic functions required for a transaction. Blockchain technology is a secure, immutable, and distributed ledger system that addresses common issues in traditional transaction systems, including data security, transaction speed, and confidentiality5. Ashish Kumar Jha et al.2 discuss the integration of blockchain with platforms like banks and e-commerce sites to facilitate swift and secure transactions. While they highlight the benefits, their work lacks detailed implementation strategies, a gap our paper aims to address by providing a concrete system architecture and functional prototype. A blockchain network consists of user nodes for clients and verification nodes managed by banks, as noted by6. This distributed setup enables verification nodes to validate transactions, confirm accounts, and generate blocks containing multiple transactions. Clients use user nodes to access account histories and initiate transactions. However, managing the complexity of multiple node types and ensuring their seamless interoperability in a large-scale banking environment presents significant challenges not fully explored in their conceptual model. Additionally, Hamburger et al1 illustrates how a single database can simplify the KYC (Know Your Customer) process across banks through blockchain technology, thereby expediting transaction timelines for users sending money worldwide. Eliminating intermediaries further enhances transaction speed7,8,9. This approach is promising for reducing administrative overhead, but it necessitates extensive collaboration with regulatory bodies and may encounter legal hurdles related to data privacy and cross-border data sharing. Blockchain also secures banking transactions without the need for tokens, effectively addressing challenges like node, media, and communication failures, developed by Seymour et al.10. Banks would manage all transactions directly, generating new blocks linked to the blockchain. A potential limitation of this method is the performance implications and scalability issues that might arise from block generation without the incentivization of miners, which could impact network throughput. Mohamed1 proposed a blockchain-based architecture for secure mobile payments, highlighting the necessity for secure applications. Yi-Wei Chang et al.11 developed a decentralized e-marketplace platform that documents each transaction step on the blockchain, providing electronic proof in case of disputes. While innovative, the generalizability of their framework to diverse mobile payment systems remains uncertain, and its implementation may require extensive changes to existing marketplace infrastructures. Furthermore, research on blockchain frameworks has resulted in a proposed electronic voting system that tackles existing system shortcomings12. Despite its potential for enhanced integrity, voter privacy and overall system integrity may still be concerns that require robust cryptographic solutions beyond basic blockchain implementation. It is also worth noting that various consensus algorithms beyond Ethereum's Proof of Stake, such as Proof of Authority (PoA) or Delegated Proof of Stake (DPoS), offer different trade-offs in terms of decentralization, scalability, and energy consumption, which could be explored for specific banking applications. Summary of Related Works on Blockchain Technology is presented in Table 1 Table 2 highlights key issues in current banking systems, including centralization leading to inefficiency, high transaction fees and latency causing financial losses, and data vulnerability, which raises concerns about theft and falsification. Centralization in traditional banking creates bottlenecks, single points of failure, and slow reconciliation processes, directly impacting efficiency and increasing operational costs. These challenges emphasize the need for improvements in security, efficiency, and trust within the banking sector. High transaction fees, particularly for cross-border payments, coupled with long wait times, result in significant financial losses for both institutions and customers, hindering liquidity and economic activity. Furthermore, the inherent lack of tamper-proof mechanisms in traditional banking data makes it susceptible to alteration without proper oversight, leading to concerns about fraud, theft, and falsification of records. Blockchain technology can simplify transactions by doing away with the need for middlemen like clearinghouses. This has the potential to save expenses for banks as well as clients by greatly accelerating the processing of transactions. The primary driving force behind blockchain technology is the need for decentralization, which is accomplished by allocating compute duties to each blockchain network node. One of the issues with traditional systems that decentralization addresses is the single point of failure. Decentralization also fosters censorship resistance and enhances financial inclusion by lowering barriers to entry for unbanked populations. The fundamental technology of blockchain generates an unchangeable transaction record. By making it extremely impossible to change or modify financial data, this can increase security. However, it is important to acknowledge that while decentralization offers significant advantages, it also introduces complexities related to regulatory compliance and governance. The main and summarised objectives of our method are as follows: Enhance transparency and security Leverage blockchain technology to ensure immutable transaction records, fostering user trust and enabling independent verification of all financial activities within the banking system. This specifically aims to establish a cryptographically secured and auditable financial ledger, fundamentally transforming how trust is established and maintained. Streamline user experience Develop intuitive interfaces and features like Metamask integration to facilitate seamless navigation and management of digital assets for all users. Expand functional capabilities Incorporate mobile payment systems, third-party logins, and account creation features to enhance accessibility and support diverse transaction needs within the evolving cashless economy. Figure 1 shows the system architecture of the proposed blockchain framework which illustrates the working procedure of the overall system. User interaction on the System UI and how different system features are handled. Besides, after the contract is deployed on Sepolia Testnet, and when the smart contract executes, the transactions are stored in Blockchain. System architecture of the proposed blockchain framework. The proposed framework built on two fundamental systems: one is the backend which manages Smart Contract activities and the user interface (UI) which interacts with the Smart Contract to carry out user actions. Our system is built on using the Ethereum blockchain which is a decentralized blockchain with smart contract functionality. Ethereum provides a decentralized, public ledger system perfectly suited for secure and transparent financial transactions. Transactions are immutable and auditable by all participants, fostering trust and eliminating the need for centralized intermediaries. Ether is the native cryptocurrency of the platform. Among cryptocurrencies, ether is second only to bitcoin in market capitalization. It is open-source software. Our smart contract is written using the solidity programming language. Solidity is a high-level, object-oriented programming language specifically created for writing smart contracts on the Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM). Ensuring the security of smart contracts is crucial in the realm of blockchain technology. Smart contracts are immutable and self-executing codes essential for various decentralized applications and financial transactions. Smart contracts cannot be changed once they are deployed on the blockchain, in contrast to traditional software. Because of this immutability, extensive testing is more essential than ever. We are using the Chai assertion library to test out the contract. We perform unit testing and staging to ensure smart contracts work as intended without unexpected behavior or errors. Deployment of a smart contract to any blockchain network is the most challenging part using a local development environment. That's why we use Hardhat which is an Ethereum Development Environment. Hardhat facilitates the deployment of smart contracts to various blockchain networks, including Hardhat's own local network for testing purposes. This allows you to thoroughly test your contracts in a safe and controlled environment before deploying them. After that, we deploy out smart contract into the Seploia Testnet which is a public test network for the Ethereum blockchain. The Sepolia Testnet provides a safe and cost-effective environment to thoroughly test and debug our smart contracts before deploying them on the Ethereum mainnet. This mitigates risks and ensures a smooth user experience. Deploying a smart contract to any blockchain network requires gas fees, which are necessary to execute transactions on the network. To cover these gas fees, we typically need a cryptocurrency wallet that holds the native token of the blockchain network. We are using Metamask crypto wallet. This wallet allows to sign transactions and pay for the computational resources required for deploying and interacting with smart contracts. After completing the development of a smart contract, the next step is integrating it into a web application to enable user interaction. For the frontend development of the web application, we use React js which is a popular JavaScript library for building user interfaces. React.js was chosen for its component-based architecture, declarative programming style, and large, active community, which collectively enable the development of highly modular, reusable, and maintainable UI components. React.js enables us to create a user friendly and responsive web application for interacting with our financial functionalities. By leveraging React's component-based architecture, we can ensure a modular and maintainable codebase. To connect our web application with the smart contract deployed on the Ethereum blockchain, we utilize a Web4-compatible library such as Ethers.js. Ethers.js was selected over alternatives like Web3.js due to its lighter footprint, improved type safety, built-in support for Ethereum Name Service (ENS), and a more streamlined Application Binary Interface (ABI) handling, which collectively enhance security and development efficiency. It simplifies complex blockchain operations like sending transactions, receiving transaction details, and managing accounts. This allows us to develop our user interface components in React.js while seamlessly integrating with the underlying Ethereum blockchain functionality. The system architecture, as depicted in Fig. 1, operates by having the User Interface (UI) capture user inputs for financial transactions (e.g., deposit, withdrawal, transfer). These inputs are then transmitted via Ethers.js to the deployed smart contract on the Ethereum network. The smart contract, acting as the backend logic, processes these requests, updates the ledger state, and records the immutable transaction details on the blockchain. Metamask or the custom wallet facilitates the signing of these transactions, ensuring user authentication and authorization. Data, such as account balances and transaction histories, is primarily managed by the smart contract's state variables and recorded as events on the blockchain, which the UI can then query and display to the user. The proposed blockchain-based framework relies on Ethereum smart contracts for executing core financial operations, including account creation, deposits, withdrawals, and peer-to-peer transfers. Each of these processes can be analyzed in terms of computational and time complexity. We incorporates three key algorithms: Ethereum account generation, Ether deposit, and Ether withdrawal with complex validation. Their computational and time complexities are analyzed as follows: This algorithm performs key derivation, public key generation, hashing, and address extraction. Each step operates on fixed-size inputs, leading to constant complexity. The heaviest operation is elliptic curve point multiplication in ECDSA, which remains constant time for fixed key sizes13. Execution time is negligible (milliseconds), independent of the number of users. The deposit process involves transaction creation, signature verification, balance check, and broadcasting to the Ethereum network. All operations are constant time: In our prototype, execution time is not limited by computational steps, but primarily by block confirmation latency inherent to Ethereum's consensus mechanism. On the Sepolia testnet, deposits confirm within 12–16 seconds on average, while Ethereum mainnet confirmation requires 12–25 seconds depending on congestion14,15. The withdrawal process executes balance verification, withdrawal limit checks, timing constraints, balance update, and transfer. Each step is constant time, yielding: As with deposits, actual execution time is determined by consensus latency and network throughput rather than algorithmic growth. Ethereum Layer 1 throughput is typically 15–30 TPS, while Layer 2 solutions can scale to thousands of TPS16. Each transaction executes in constant time. For n transactions processed sequentially, the overall computational complexity is linear: Practical performance is further influenced by blockchain characteristics such as throughput, consensus latency, and gas consumption. Gas cost analysis reinforces constant complexity, as deposits, withdrawals, and transfers consumed stable gas units (78,364; 61,207; and 41,667 respectively), regardless of input size13. By contrast, traditional banking settlements involve multiple intermediaries (correspondent banks, clearing houses), creating multi-step verification and reconciliation processes that may extend settlement to 2–3 business days17,18. The proposed framework introduces several technical innovations in its design that strengthen both efficiency and security of banking settlements: Smart contract–based settlement All banking operations such as deposits, withdrawals, and transfers are executed by Ethereum smart contracts. This ensures deterministic execution, immutability, and transparency, reducing dependency on multiple intermediaries in traditional banking. Gas-efficient contract design The smart contract functions were structured to minimize redundant computations, thereby lowering gas costs while maintaining correctness. This enhances scalability and cost predictability for high-volume financial transactions. Wallet-centric user custody By integrating MetaMask and custom wallets, users retain full control of their private keys and assets. Unlike conventional systems where banks act as sole custodians, this design significantly reduces risks of centralized fraud or mismanagement. Direct frontend–blockchain integration The use of Ether.js in the React.js interface allows seamless communication with Ethereum smart contracts. This bypasses centralized servers, ensuring that user interactions are securely and directly recorded on-chain. Consensus-level security By building on the Ethereum network, the framework inherits strong distributed consensus guarantees. These provide fault tolerance, immutability, and protection against fraudulent or conflicting transactions, ensuring secure and reliable financial settlements. These innovations distinguish the proposed approach from prior blockchain applications in banking3,5,6. The quantitative evaluation of these design choices, including gas efficiency, transaction latency, and settlement speed, is presented in the Outcome and Result Analysis section. To situate our framework within prior research, we compared it against representative blockchain-based banking studies. Joseph and Karunan5 proposed a decentralized settlement system but without wallet-level integration or gas optimization. Muneeb et al.6 developed SmartCon, focusing on scalability, though lacking testbed validation on Ethereum. Bagrecha et al.3 outlined blockchain's potential in banking but presented only a conceptual model without complexity or latency analysis. In contrast, the present work contributes: Gas-optimized smart contracts validated on the Ethereum Sepolia Testnet with real gas benchmarks. Seamless wallet integration (MetaMask/custom) ensuring user custody of funds. Direct frontend–blockchain interaction through Ether.js, removing centralized servers. Table 3 highlights these distinctions. Our proposed blockchain-based approach system as depicts on Fig. 2, uses the Ethereum blockchain and Ether (ETH) as the native currency to achieve unparalleled efficiency and security within these critical financial processes. Our system leverages the capabilities of Ethereum to offer a core set of financial functionalities built upon the Ethereum blockchain. These functionalities include: New user accounts are created on the Ethereum blockchain. This generates a unique Ethereum address for each user, acting as their public identifier and the destination for deposits and transactions. User can create accounts in two different ways. (1) Our Own wallet or (2) Using user Existing account on the Metamask wallet This is a summary of how our wallet creates a user account in Ethereum, starting with a seed phrase , then a private key, then a public key, and finally generate address: A seed phrase is a collection of words that serves as a private key; it can also be referred to as a mnemonic phrase. It's a method of encoding a private key so that people may more easily recall and record it. A key derivation function (KDF) like BIP32 or BIP39 can be used to create a private key from a seed phrase. These functions take a seed phrase and other input parameters and use a mathematical procedure to create a private key. After obtaining a private key, you can create a public key using it. The Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA), is used to generate a 64-byte (or 512-bit) value from a private key in Ethereum. Using the Keccak-256 hash function to extract a 20-byte (or 160-bit) value from a public key and use that value to construct an Ethereum address. The Ethereum address is this value, which is used to determine who owns the address. User can also use their existing account on the Metamask wallet to create account into our system. Ethereum Account Generation from Seed Phrase Ether (ETH) Deposit Process Users can deposit Ether (ETH) into their accounts. This process involves initiating a transaction on the Ethereum network and sending ETH from an external source (like a crypto exchange) to the user's Ethereum address. Once initiated, the transaction is broadcasted to the Ethereum network, where it enters the mempool (a queue of pending transactions). Miners or validators on the network then select the transaction from the mempool, validate it by verifying the digital signature and the sender's account balance, and finally, include it in a new block. It is permanently recorded on the blockchain, a public and immutable ledger. This ensures the transaction cannot be altered or reversed, providing security and transparency. The user can monitor the transaction status in real time by using blockchain explorers like Etherscan, which track the progress of transactions on the Ethereum network. These explorers allow users to enter their transaction hash (a unique identifier for the transaction) to view detailed information, including the number of confirmations received, the gas fee paid, and the current status (pending, confirmed, or failed). Figure (a) Meta mask creation, (b) Deposit Ether Diagram, (c) Withdraw-amount-diagram, (d) Transfer-ether-diagram. Users can withdraw Ether (ETH) from their accounts by initiating a transaction on the Ethereum network. This process involves specifying the recipient's Ethereum address and the amount of ETH to be transferred. Once the withdrawal request is made, the transaction is broadcasted to the Ethereum network, where it enters the mempool for processing. Similar to deposits, smart contracts validate and secure the transaction on the blockchain during a withdrawal. When a user initiates a withdrawal, the smart contract governing the account automatically verifies several key aspects of the transaction. This includes ensuring the user has sufficient ETH in their account to cover the withdrawal, and checking that the transaction adheres to any predefined rules or conditions set by the platform, such as withdrawal limits or timing constraints. ETH Withdrawal on Ethereum Network with Complex Validation Users can transfer Ether (ETH) to other accounts on the Ethereum network, by utilizing the blockchain's core transfer capabilities. Users initiate a transaction by specifying the recipient's address and the amount of ether to be sent. The Ethereum network validates and secures these transfers through its consensus mechanism, ensuring that transactions are transparent, immutable, and resistant to tampering. By enabling seamless and efficient ETH transfers, Ethereum showcases its potential to serve as a foundation for a secure and transparent decentralized banking system, where users have full control over their funds without relying on intermediaries. These core functionalities demonstrate the potential of Ethereum to build a secure and transparent banking system. Throughout this paper, we will dive deeper into the technical aspects of how these functionalities are implemented on the Ethereum blockchain, exploring the benefits and challenges associated with such an approach. Using blockchain technology, our proposed system combines user-friendly interfaces for smooth operation with transparent and impenetrable financial transactions. This project successfully developed a prototype for a blockchain-based banking system utilizing Etherjs, Reactjs, and Solidity. The key achievements include: A user-friendly Reactjs online application enables peer-to-peer transfers as depicts on Figs. 3 and 4, account creation, and balance viewing. Etherjs enables smooth communication between these functionalities and the blockchain. The prototype successfully demonstrated near-real-time transaction processing for deposits, withdrawals, and transfers on the Sepolia testnet, with average transaction finality observed within seconds, reflecting the efficiency gains of a blockchain-based approach. Client-server architecture. Peer-to-peer architecture. Smart contracts automate transaction processing and account administration and those are two essential banking functions. This fosters security and trust by doing away with the necessity for a central authority. The implemented smart contracts, comprising approximately 500 lines of Solidity code, encapsulate core banking logic for managing user balances, processing transfers, and handling withdrawal requests. Their modular design facilitated independent testing of functions like ‘fund()‘, ‘withdraw()‘, and ‘transferEther()‘, ensuring robust and predictable behavior. Challenges encountered during development primarily involved gas optimization and ensuring reentrancy protection, which were addressed through careful code structuring and adherence to best practices. Deployment of Smart Contract is depict on Fig. 5. Deployment of smart contract. Transaction history. Algorithm of deploying the code to the testnet: Write a smart contract code containing fund(), withdraw(), transferEther() functions using solidity programming language and compile it using solc compiler. Specify the target blockchain network like testnet, mainnet. Create a blockchain account with sufficient funds to cover deployment costs and specify the contract bytecode and other relevant parameters like constructor arguments,gas limit, gas price etc. Sign the transaction using the private key of the account that will deploy the contract and send it to the blockchain network for processing. Wait for the transaction to be mined and confirmed by the network and retrieve the contract address generated by the deployment. Therefore transaction history using our proposed system in sepolia testnet is shown on Fig. 6: Users can connect to the blockchain and communicate with the banking application through MetaMask shown in Fig. 7, a well-known cryptocurrency wallet. This integration simplifies user onboarding and transaction signing. Metamask integration. The main transaction process of the system is illustrated in Fig. 8. To transfer funds to another user, the initial step for a user is to create an account. Once they have acquired the necessary amount of ether, their account will be established, allowing them to initiate transfers. After entering the desired transfer amount, the user can proceed. The Smart Contract will manage the transaction details and promptly credit the specified amount to the recipient's Ethereum wallet. Similarly, the first user can request funds from another user, who can then transfer the required amount from their wallet to the first user. Additionally, users can withdraw funds from the bank by submitting a withdrawal request for the specified amount, which will subsequently deduct the necessary ethers from their Ethereum wallet. Money transferring process. Our proposed system is more secure and transparent than the traditional system. Its speed is also high compared to the traditional system because there is no need to a middleman in our system. The comparison between our proposed blockchain based banking system and traditional system depicts in Table 4. A comprehensive analysis reveals distinct advantages of our blockchain-based system over traditional banking frameworks across several key performance indicators. In terms of transaction speed, while traditional domestic transfers can be instantaneous, cross-border payments often incur delays of days due to multiple intermediaries and reconciliation processes. Our system, leveraging blockchain, enables near-instantaneous cross-border settlements, significantly reducing latency. Regarding costs, traditional banking involves various fees (e.g., wire transfer fees, foreign exchange markups, intermediary charges), which can be substantial. Our system primarily incurs gas fees, which are often lower for direct peer-to-peer transfers, thereby reducing overall transaction expenses. From a security perspective, traditional systems, despite robust measures, remain susceptible to centralized database breaches and insider threats. Our blockchain-based system, with its cryptographic security, distributed ledger, and immutability, offers enhanced resilience against data tampering and unauthorized access. Transparency is another critical differentiator; traditional banking offers limited visibility into transaction flows, whereas our system provides a publicly verifiable and auditable record of all transactions on the blockchain. Finally, user control is significantly enhanced, as users maintain direct custody of their funds through their cryptographic keys, unlike traditional banking where funds are held by the institution. In this performance benchmark, we have tested our smart contract's efficiency on Sepolia Ethereum Testnet. Sepolia has the features of the Ethereum Mainnet and is suitable for doing performance analysis. Unlike Mainnet, Sepolia Testnet uses the no-value token SepoliaETH to cover its gas fees. To relate the actual cost of a transaction, we compare the no-value token to the Mainnet's token, providing a clear view of the fees. Throughput, gas cost, and latency are the key performance evaluation metrics. In our paper, these metrics represent the overall system's stability. In blockchain, throughput is the rate of transactions happening per second. This rate can be calculated by performing several transactions at a time over the difference between the EndTime (E) and StartTime (S) of the transactions in seconds. The formula for throughput is Where the duration is calculated as We need to divide the difference by 1000 to convert the time from milliseconds to seconds. A higher throughput means a much more efficient system. A system that can manage a huge number of transactions per second. Gas cost is the metric that determines the cost of every transaction. Which is another important factor to consider. Different functionality of smart contracts can consume different amounts of gas. The Gas cost is calculated by multiplying the gas consumed by the per-unit gas price. We need to divide by \(10^{9}\) to convert Gwei to SepoliaEth \(\left( 1 \ \text {Gwei} = 10^{-9} \ \text {SepoliaEth} \right)\). Lower gas cost means a lower fee per transaction. Gas cost analysis of proposed system. On the other hand, Latency is what determines the time it takes to be included in the Blockchain for a single transaction. It's computed by taking the difference between the transaction confirmation time and the submission time for a single transaction. This provides a quick look at how fast the Blockchain is processing and validating transactions. Latency is expressed as Using these metrics, this study aims to demonstrate the efficiency of the Blockchain by comparing it with its non-blockchain counterparts. In our test, depicts in Fig. 9, we found that in the Sepolia Testnet, the Deposit, Transfer, and Withdrawl operations consume respectively 78,364, 41,667, and 61,207 gas units every time. For the Deposit, the Gas cost would be every time. The same method can be used for Transfer and Withdraw. But as it is a Testnet, it doesn't carry real-world value. In the traditional banking card system (e.g., Visa, American Express, Mastercard), the transaction cost is fixed and unrelated to the computational power. The merchant pays a fee of 1.5% to 3.5% of the total transaction's amount. The fee for a transaction increases as the amount increases. On the Ethereum Mainnet, the cost of a transaction or a transaction fee is based on the computational power consumed by a transaction. For example, if we consider every deposit transaction on Mainnet with 78,364 consumed gas and at a gas price of 15 Gwei, then the cost for this transaction would be $4.11. Layer 2s would provide more efficiency on gas fees, ranging from $0.05 to $0.25 on every deposit transaction. Latency analysis of proposed system. Transaction throughput of proposed system. From Fig. 10, if we look at the latency, the data retrieval from the blockchain is less than 1 second on average. Sepolia Testnet has a fixed block rate of 12 seconds, which means that every new block will be merged on the blockchain every 12 seconds, plus the time for the transaction to be picked up by a validator. We found that, on average, the deposit, transfer, and withdrawal take 16 seconds (Time to Inclusion) to write on the Testnet. On the Ethereum Mainnet, the time to inclusion is similar to the Testnet and takes 12-25 seconds based on network congestion. However, the finality takes approximately 13 minutes. The layer 2s offer significantly less time to inclusion, but their finality is longer than that of layer 1. For the traditional banking system, the execution time of transactions is also very fast, typically 2-3 seconds. However, this is only the approval of the bank. But the finality of the banking system takes up to 1-3 business days to completely transfer the funds among the banks. TPS analysis of ethereum and traditional banking system. The ability of a system to handle transactions is determined by its throughput, which is expressed in Transactions Per Second (TPS). The Ethereum Mainnet (Layer 1) and the Sepolia Testnet are intended to be identical, and both are subject to network consensus rules. Their throughput as shown in Fig. 11, which usually handles 15–30 TPS, is essentially constrained. This limits scalability but guarantees decentralization and security. Ethereum Layer 2s (such as Arbitrum and Optimism) overcome the limitations of Layer 1 and have the TPS ranging from 1,000 to 7,000. By processing transactions off-chain and submitting compressed data to Layer 1, they achieve a dramatically higher throughput. For comparison, the traditional payment system represented by Visa's global network (VisaNet) is a highly optimized, centralized system. It sets the standard for high-volume transaction processing, designed for massive scale. This is based on the theoretical numbers of banking card systems, which claim 65,000 TPS for Visa and 5,000 for Mastercard, with their practical TPS ranging from 1300 to 2000 as shown in Fig. 12. Our banking system, which is built on blockchain technology, introduces revolutionary concepts that fundamentally transform traditional banking procedures. By leveraging decentralized ledger technology, it ensures unparalleled transparency, security, and efficiency in financial transactions. The incorporation of smart contracts automates agreements, eliminates the need for intermediaries, and significantly reduces operational costs, providing users with a seamless banking experience. In our innovative system, we offer a range of cutting-edge features designed to enhance user engagement and streamline banking operations: Metamask connection We have developed a user-friendly button that allows users to effortlessly connect their Metamask accounts. This integration facilitates secure and direct interaction with the blockchain, empowering users to manage their digital assets efficiently. Account interface The account interface serves as a comprehensive dashboard for users to monitor their financial activities. Through this interface, users can easily view their account balance, deposit and withdraw funds, and transfer ether from their account with just a few clicks. The intuitive design ensures that even those new to blockchain technology can navigate the system with ease. All account interface This section provides users with visibility into all accounts that interact with our banking system. Users can not only view the transaction history of each account but also track their own transactions, fostering a sense of accountability and trust within the community. Enhancing security Our method transforms financial security by utilizing blockchain technology. Using a distributed ledger, each transaction is tracked as a block that is connected to the one before it to create an unchangeable chain. Because there is no longer a need for middlemen, there is less chance of fraud and data breaches. Furthermore, our utilised blockchain uses cryptographic encryption to protect private data, guaranteeing its secrecy and integrity. Smart contracts automate procedures, reduce errors, and boost productivity. They are self-executing contracts with predetermined terms. Moreover, the consensus method makes it very difficult to falsify or alter the data because it requires several nodes to validate transactions. This coordinated effort guarantees the highest level of security for banking transactions while fortifying the system's resistance to hackers. While the system is designed to be highly resistant to common cyberattacks due to its decentralized and cryptographic nature, it is important to note that no system is entirely immune. Potential vulnerabilities could arise from smart contract bugs, user private key compromise, or sophisticated social engineering attacks, necessitating continuous security audits and user education. Our system's data is securely stored on the Alchemy Sepolia Testnet, allowing users to scrutinize every transaction's hash value, block number, date, transaction amount, gas fees, and other relevant details. This feature underscores the transparency of our system, as users can verify each transaction independently. Moreover, the architecture of the Sepolia Testnet ensures that no one can alter transaction data once it has been recorded. This immutability is a cornerstone of our banking system, providing users with confidence that their financial data remains secure and unchangeable. The combination of transparency and immutability not only enhances user trust but also sets a new standard for how banking systems can operate in a digital age. Through these advancements, our blockchain-based banking system is poised to redefine the landscape of financial services, making banking more accessible, efficient, and secure for all users. A smart contract-based transaction solution for Blockchain-based transaction processes is being presented by this project. This guarantees that the funds of users are protected by our system and that there will never be any financial loss. Compared to the previous manually operated transaction applications, such as bank transactions, this is an upgrade. Transactions in a variety of sectors can be made quick, safe, immutable, decentralized, fraud-free, and transparent with Ethereum-based transaction systems. Because it can meet the demands of the impending cashless economy, the banking sector can fully rely on this technology in the future. Finance firms will use decentralized finance, which eliminates the need for investors to deposit their money with a central bank. This work represents a proof-of-concept and should not be interpreted as a production-ready banking platform. The results, while promising, are based on a limited deployment on a test network and without integration with real financial infrastructures. Future work will focus on extending the platform with mobile payment integration, third-party login mechanisms, enhanced security auditing of smart contracts, and usability testing with end-users. Specifically, future work will involve developing native iOS and Android mobile applications with features like biometric authentication and push notifications, integrating decentralized identity solutions (e.g., Verifiable Credentials) for robust KYC/AML compliance, conducting formal verification and continuous security audits of smart contracts, and performing extensive user studies to refine the user experience. Furthermore, rigorous performance benchmarks will be established to measure transaction throughput (TPS) and latency under various load conditions, and strategies for interoperability with existing traditional financial APIs will be explored to facilitate real-world adoption. A real-world pilot with measurable performance benchmarks and user studies will be required before deploying such systems in practical financial services environments. While our blockchain framework demonstrates potential for secure and transparent financial transactions, several limitations exist. First, the system was only tested in a controlled testnet environment and not connected to real banking APIs or financial institutions. This implies that the system's performance under real-world network congestion, variable gas prices, and regulatory compliance requirements remains untested. Second, the evaluation lacks formal benchmarks for speed, throughput, or fault tolerance. Third, the system does not include features like mobile application support, user identity verification (KYC), or audit compliance mechanisms necessary for real-world deployment. The absence of these features means the current prototype cannot address critical aspects of user onboarding, anti-money laundering regulations, or financial reporting standards required for practical banking operations. These limitations will be addressed in future iterations of the work. Ultimately, the vision for this research is to contribute to a future where blockchain technology serves as a foundational layer for a truly inclusive, efficient, and secure global financial ecosystem, moving beyond theoretical concepts to practical, impactful implementations19,20,21. No datasets were generated or analyzed during the current study. The system was evaluated through simulated tasks on a prototype deployed on the Ethereum Sepolia Testnet. Therefore, there is no raw data to share. However, the prototype source code and smart contract implementation are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request. Mohamed, A. O. Y. Hayes Says New Altcoins Will Work for the User, Not Hype: PEPENODE Next Crypto to Explode?
Source: Bitcoinist.com    Published: 2025-11-07 11:50:13

Quick Facts: Arthur Hayes, co-founder of BitMEX and one of the most closely watched voices in crypto macro-analysis, has argued that the next altcoin bull run will be driven by utility, users, and paying customers, not hype. That's a distinct shift from the way things have been so far, where projects rely on hype and momentum to build up enough of a user base to establish themselves. Hayes highlights that those days are coming to an end – and the next crypto to explode could be poised to take advantage. In his recent remarks, Hayes said the era of projects thriving solely on token hype and venture backing is coming to an end. Instead, projects with real users, paying clients, and sustainable value-sharing models will shape the new cycle. That's distinct from previous cycles, where projects launched innovative projects – but never had a good market fit, never retained customers, and never generated the revenue they needed to stay alive. Historically, altcoin seasons have come in waves, from the ICO mania of 2017 to DeFi Summer in 2020 and meme-coin explosions in 2023–24. Each cycle brought new innovation, but many tokens eventually faded once hype outpaced product-market fit. Amidst this shift, one new presale – PepeNode – is gaining attention. Though it carries a playful meme aesthetic, it's designed around an actual mine-to-earn virtual node ecosystem, directly appealing to the ‘utility + user' vision Hayes outlined. At its core, PepeNode ($PEPENODE) transforms the familiar meme-coin playbook into a gamified virtual mining experience, where users deploy digital nodes, upgrade facilities, and earn $PEPENODE rewards – all without real-world hardware or energy costs. The presale offers $PEPENODE at $0.0011363 per token, with a total supply of 210 billion tokens minted on the Ethereum network (ERC-20 standard). Early participants can purchase via ETH, USDT, BNB, or even credit/debit cards and stake $PEPENODE tokens for 621% dynamic APY; you can learn more about how to buy $PEPENODE with our guide. The approach introduces a ‘mine-to-earn' structure designed for accessibility and engagement. It's a gamified approach to meme coin mining, delivering meme coin rewards without any of the technical and energy barriers typical of Proof-of-Work mining. Key functional elements include: The presale's appeal lies in its blend of meme familiarity with functional engagement, offering something to do, not just to hold. As Hayes noted, the market is turning toward projects that give users tangible reasons to participate. Our own price prediction sees $PEPENODE reaching $0.0072 from its current price by 2026, delivering 533% rewards to early participants. As Hayes heralds a new era for the best altcoins, PepeNode joins the running as a project delivering utility and a genuine use case – not just hype. Start mining meme coins. Join the PEPENODE presale today! This content is for informational purposes only. Always do your own research (DYOR). Not financial advice (NFA). Authored by Bogdan Patru for Bitcoinist — https://bitcoinist.com/hayes-says-new-altcoins-work-for-user-as-pepenode-might-be-next For updates and exclusive offers enter your email. As a crypto writer, Bogdan's responsibilities are split between researching and writing articles and entertaining the team with his humor bordering on the politically incorrect, an aspiring Bill Burr, if you will. Thanks to his 12+ years of writing experience in just as many fields, including tech, cybersecurity, modelling, fitness, crypto, and other topics-that-shall-not-be-named, he's become a genuine asset to the team. While his position as a senior writer at PrivacyAffairs thought him valuable lessons about the power of self-management, his entire writing career was and is an exercise in self-improvement. Now, he's ready to sink his teeth into crypto and teach people how to take control of their own money on the blockchain. With fiat as an eternally devaluing currency, Bitcoin and altcoins seem like the best-fitting alternative for Bogdan. Bogdan's biggest professional accomplishment, aside from securing a position as a main writer for Bitcoinist, was his 5-year run as a writing manager at Blackwood Productions, where he coordinated a team of four writers. During that time, he learned the value of teamwork and that of creating a working environment that breeds efficiency, positivity, and friendship. Crypto Markets Today: Bitcoin (BTC) Defends $100K Price as Traders Flee Altcoins
Source: CoinDesk    Published: 2025-11-07 11:30:37

The crypto market compounded a negative week with a continued drawdown on Friday. Bitcoin BTC$102,012.68 dropped to $100,600 and ether ETH$3,355.00 is languishing as $3,270. The move appears to be in line with the wider crypto market trend of late, which has seen BTC lose 18% of its value over the past 30 days. Both the CoinDesk 5 Index (CD5) of the largest, most active tokens and the broader CoinDesk 20 Index (CD20) have lost about 3% in the past 24 hours. The fallout can still be attributed to comments out of the Federal Reserve earlier in the week that suggested a potential cooling of the rate-cutting cycle, causing a rise in the U.S. dollar and a slump in risk assets. The altcoin market, with the exception of AI tokens, is performing worse than bitcoin, with the "altcoin season" index at 22/100, its lowest in more than 90 days. Submit ICO Home » News » Ethereum Price Prediction: ETH Risks Breakdown as Traders Look for Safer Momentum Dimitar is a Top 1% SEO strategist and content expert known for scaling iGaming, Web3, SaaS, and E-commerce brands through AI-ready, E-E-A-T optimized content. With… Kai Man Ng is an editor and translator with a strong passion for crypto, blockchain, and Web3 technologies. He specializes in transforming complex technical concepts… Ethereum price prediction is on edge as ETH trades at $3,336.09, facing downward pressure and a red day across major exchanges. While macro fear continues to dominate, meme tokens and low-cap presales are starting to absorb the attention. Maxi Doge, a meme coin built on Ethereum, has crossed $3.92M in its presale, offering high staking rewards while ETH struggles to hold the line. With RSI in deep oversold territory and whales shifting their capital, Ethereum's ability to hold key support could dictate not just ETH's short-term bounce, but the path altcoins and presale markets follow next. Ethereum is in a fragile state. The current price of $3,336.09 reflects a 1.36% daily drop, and more importantly, ETH sits on a key support zone that's been tested multiple times this month. This setup opens the door for a short-term bounce, possibly back toward the $3,900 level if bulls step in. But if that support cracks, Ethereum could accelerate downward – and drag altcoins with it. The threat of a deeper pullback is real, and even meme traders are watching it closely. Robert Kiyosaki's “massive crash” warning may sound theatrical, but ETH's structure shows genuine vulnerability. A breakdown here could confirm his bearish outlook – and set off wider panic across the altcoin space. Despite short-term bounce potential, Ethereum is showing signs of exhaustion. Even before today's dip, the token failed to reclaim $3,900, a level that has served as major resistance multiple times. With whales offloading and momentum weakening, ETH looks stuck. Traders tracking Ethereum price prediction scenarios know that failure to climb above this resistance could lock ETH into a sideways or even bearish channel – especially if macro sentiment stays heavy. Altcoins, especially those tied closely to Ethereum's ecosystem, are already feeling this drag. The market isn't just watching ETH – it's reacting ahead of it. Robert Kiyosaki is back with his usual warning: “MASSIVE CRASH BEGINNING.” He's told audiences that silver, gold, Bitcoin, and Ethereum are the assets to hold. But traders familiar with his past know he's posted over 30 crash warnings in the last 12 months – many of which were followed by rallies, not collapses. Still, this time around, Ethereum's chart is showing real weakness, and Kiyosaki's timing happens to align with the current breakdown risk. If ETH fails to hold support, there's a real chance of a sharp move to the downside – with $2,900 or even $2,500 in play. While some may dismiss Kiyosaki's words, the chart doesn't lie. And if this support breaks, the Ethereum price prediction narrative could flip fast from recovery to capitulation. While Ethereum struggles to stay above water, Maxi Doge is exploding in presale activity. The token is built on Ethereum and has positioned itself as the “Ethereum saver” in community memes – but behind the humor, it's offering real numbers: With a staking pool already live and strong tokenomics, it's catching attention from ETH holders who want to stay within the Ethereum network but are looking for early upside, fixed rewards, and presale momentum. And while Ethereum price charts look shaky, Maxi Doge is showing clean, trackable growth – with time-sensitive incentives and a visible countdown. Traders aren't just betting on ETH anymore – they're rotating into Ethereum-powered tokens or best altcoins that give them more upside per dollar. Ripple drives growth in the blockchain ecosystem with institutional-grade security measures
Source: South China Morning Post    Published: 2025-11-07 08:00:09

The digital asset infrastructure provider brings enhanced self-custody technology to financial firms in the Asia-Pacific region Blockchain technology and digital assets, including cryptocurrency, are already moving beyond their initial limitations as niche technologies to shape a more accessible, secure and impactful ecosystem. Ninety per cent of finance leaders believe these technologies will have a profound effect on the industry within three years, according to a recent survey conducted by Ripple, a digital asset infrastructure company. As compelling use cases emerge – from cross-border payments to tokenisation of real-world assets – the first challenge any firm must address is safe and secure custody. The institutional adoption of blockchain technology hinges on the ability to store, access and protect digital assets with confidence. “The next wave of growth in digital assets won't be driven by retail speculation; it will be driven by institutional utility – and the foundation for that is secure custody,” says Jack Cullinane, Ripple's senior director, commercial, Asia-Pacific. “In hubs like Hong Kong, regulatory clarity is accelerating the move for institutions to enter this space.” Across the world's financial hubs, including Hong Kong, regulators are moving to support these new technologies by ensuring that sophisticated, institutional-grade infrastructure is balanced with robust regulatory compliance for seamless, 24-hour-a-day usability. The city's Securities and Futures Commission's rules on digital asset custody ensure institutions manage assets in line with standards seen in traditional finance, reflecting the growing market need for secure, compliant infrastructure to support exchange-traded funds, tokenised funds, stablecoin settlement and cross-border treasury and liquidity solutions. Secure crypto custody is critical to the global financial ecosystem. Ripple Custody provides the essential institutional-grade platform for securing, transferring and settling any class of tokenised financial assets. Ripple delivers the self-custody technology layer that enables banks and financial institutions to manage digital assets without compromising their existing security.
